thread.title: Three England players given permission to miss ODI series against Ireland for IPL
thread.title_full: Three England players given permission to miss ODI series against Ireland for IPL

author: Nick Hoult
title: Three England players given permission to miss ODI series against Ireland for IPL
text:
Three England players given permission to miss ODI series against Ireland for IPL Ben Stokes and Jos Buttler have both been granted permission to stay on in India for IPL Nick Hoult , Cricket News Correspondent 21 February 2017 • 5:44pm 
E ngland have given three senior one-day players permission to miss the start of the international summer to play in the Indian Premier League. 
Ben Stokes, Jos Buttler and Chris Woakes have been told they can remain in India and cash in on playing in the IPL instead of returning home to appear in England's two match series against Ireland which starts in Bristol on May 5. 
But captain Eoin Morgan, and batsmen Jason Roy and Sam Billings, will have to return early from the IPL for the first series in England against Ireland. 
Morgan missed a one dayer against Ireland in Dublin two years ago to play in the IPL but this time has to be home by May 1 for the build up to the Ireland series cutting short his time playing for Kings XI Punjab who signed him in the IPL auction for £240,000 on Monday. 
Andrew Strauss, the England team director, has encouraged the players to go to the IPL and will feel Stokes, Buttler and Woakes will gain more from playing against the leading cricketers in the world in India than an early summer series at home to Ireland. IPL most expensive signings 
T he three have been told they have to be back in England by May 14 meaning they will be able to appear in six out of the seven-week IPL season so Stokes will earn almost all of his £1.7m deal. Tymal Mills, who was signed by Royal Challengers Bangalore for £1.4m and Chris Jordan are not contracted by England and have been cleared to play in the whole IPL. 
Officials from the England & Wales Cricket Board on Tuesday told the annual general meeting of the Professional Cricketers’ Association that they hope to attract bids from all four terrestrial broadcasters when their rights deal goes to market in April. 
The ECB will tender its next broadcast rights, which start in 2020, in April if the new Twenty20 competition is approved. Further talks with the counties are due at a meeting on March 27. Stokes will be able to earn almost all of his £1.7m deal
